THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

pause.w: Well people think we've got an easy life you know.

s.w: There's nothing else to do all day but swan around.
Well most people think we do.

pause.w: Feel like cutting myself down the middle!

s.w: Hey they must have had a good meal other night.
They spent eighty odd pound on a meal!
I asked him did you have a sweet?
He said, no, he said th that you could either have one or the other.
It was a lot weren't it for

ptr.w: They have a sweet or a starters, but they didn't have them both.

s.w: There's one at sixty odd which is, I think ri quite reasonable for three but eighty odd for three of them!
It must have been a right
As long as it were worth it!
Never saw, you weren't meant to, and he says, no your mum said that we could either have a sweet or a starter, not both.

ptr.w: It sounds awfully mean don't it?

s.w: I, I said to your dad I said it's mm mm you know to actually say you can't have

ptr.w: Well if they were, if they were going home they wouldn't be having a starter and a steak and a sweet and all that lot would they?

s.w: No, but they are inconvenienced cos they're away from home but
Well I don't know, I feel happier now your dad's had that bit of a do with that bloke, cos I feel that we can go to him
and, and wi you know, hopefully get paid, there shouldn't be any problem.

pause.w: Cos that erm that Sen, that accountant obviously isn't up to much.

s.w: He promised your dad, oh it'll all be sorted within twenty four, forty eight hours and that was how many, three
I don't think he knows everything ab about that or what?
Erm he, he told him this morning on the phone, he's looked into it, he's the director and he apologizes.
He rung to apologize this morning and said that it will be sorted and you will have your cheque.
I didn't realize things were like this.
That's why you sent them the conditions!
If, if they'd have if they'd have talked to Andrew first, Andrew would have told him why we'd sent it.
Andrew can't , he's just sort of passed that, that on.
Why has it gone to somebody who ?

Well apparently it had gone to Andrew, and, Andrew had cos Andrew isn't in the office all the time, and he'd left it in the office, and I think they faxed it by th Andrew was gonna talk to somebody about it, but of course, by the time he'd got there, it'd already been done and this had happened so I'm gon na ring erm Job Centre when I get home.
I, they'll say, I know what they're gon na say.
Like, you know there's nothing they can do.

pause.w: That's why, she'll be better to stick it and then she was to Aunty Anne's.

s.w: At least when she finishes at, with Aunty Anne, it was seasonal.

ptr.w: she, she Anne's gone Aunty Anne's, she won't have to go to that job .

s.w: I'm starting to get a bit like that.

pause.w: Although I seem, I slept alright last night, but I think when you've got things on your mind no I didn't sleep alright, I was too warm, I tossed and turned most of night!
Did you, you watched the programme, the Queen did you?

s.w: Just, it's half an hour wanted to watch that on B B C two half past eight to nine o'clock.

Oh I think it'd be nice to have a video, because like, when Rebecca gets older erm cos I personally, my own feelings are that we might get Charles as King, but after Charles there won't be anything cos they'll do away with them.
I think it will get to that.
It was nice to see, and it is always nice to see the, the other side of them.
She was good with the kids weren't she?
But she was, like when she, on the trailer they said about and she said and the girls as well!
They call her granny don't they?
Granny, and she calls her mum, mummy.

pause.w: Chase, goes round all over the place don't he?
I've got some good recordings this morning!

s.w: I've got Jim from Dixons who is like, he's Lancashire but he's Bolton.
And er, Vic who is a Londoner.
Have they asked about, have you er anybody asked you yet what it what it is?

pause.w: One or two people looked, I've seen them looking but they've not actually questioned.
And it was, pretty horrible day yesterday!
I said that, I said the back door's for you but they're like concrete.

s.w: Yeah, they were very solid doors.
I mean, they do actually, they're all metal.
The frames and everything is, th the only bit of wood is the wood on the inside, on the panel!

pause.w: You see David, what he's saying to your dad this morning, let's get a meeting and go but I just feel that, I just, what's the point of going for an argument.

s.w: And, and it will be, won't
I mean, because your dad isn't gonna agree to what they're saying.
And well, I'm sure David won't anyway.
Because David knows how they were built as well as your dad
Well they've spent enough hours on them int they?
And, we made very little money on them.
And they're saying, if they do get away with knocking this money off

pause.w: I mean, they got a damn good job cos that, cos what we charged them, we charged them sixteen thousand each.

s.w: Well you think about how they were constructed and the number of man hours!

ptr.w: Try and get over the bumps as well that, I go into work and don't see Teresa that often you'd think she'd have the money ready on Friday morning wouldn't you?

s.w: Yeah, she should have it ready.
for saying I'll give it your sister.
I mean, okay, Peter give us it on Friday but wouldn't you have thought, I mean thirty quid
she would have me got cash out or dropped
There's no excuse for that, it should be there.

Sarah's told Teresa she's to work she wants her to start working till five o'clock every night, and erm she wants to work sometimes, in the summer it's gonna be

Yeah, there's no mention of any money.
He brought lads home with him.
They're back again for next few weeks.
You don't put a sheet, oh no!

pause.w: I got my gas bill this morning.

Went to look up her reading, they said had to pay I've used three times as much gas as I did three times as much gas as I needed last time
but barely done three times as much.
Mine's hundred and seventy two pound!

No I was really surprised, it was that it's that.
I expected hundred and forty at least!
Ninety three, so that's including er ten pound standing charge, you know.

Just one, one buying those damn cylinders every week to ten days!

s.w: Six pound a week she gets.

But I mean she wo she'd spend that in her in her cylinder gas

Because they, probably they won't budge.
You see, Neil's already put his side about, we worked er how can you hold us responsible for them being late in when
for a kick off anyway, you held us up for three, five months with drawings being late!

they've just co totally ignored it you see, and still put it down, so they're obviously not prepared to budge.
put it into legal hands then.

I'm wondering if I should ring them actually, from unit, and ask them if tell them what's happening and will she be able to go on Income Support if she does give it up?
Wait while your dad's out of room.

but point is Teresa, would you, if you went back on Income Support you've got that job club thing again don't you?

I'm afraid that she's not gonna
